channel.title: OpenGL textures and objects
channel.description:
If anyone can or has rendered the unpacked cache in OpenGL then i can edit the cache. :D
And im serious!!![br][size=1]Posted on: April 10, 2007, 09:07:43 AM[/size][hr]Ok Nvm I got my OpenGL renderer finished. Starting to dump textures overlays objects the works. Its going to take awhile to converte to .3DS Files but it is worth it. Also I changed the clients compression handler to support a diffrent compression for better graphics at the price of a bigger cache lol. But im all for the better graphics no matter how big the cache has to be lol.

item.title: OpenGL textures and objects
item.dc:creator: @semaphore semaphore
item.description:
@semaphore wrote:

[quote=“Javacisnotrecognized, post:41, topic:77833”]Even if the client camera and the server “camera” were always synchronized/the client sent its camera angle in every relevant packet, even by Jagexs standards that would have to be too inefficient.
Well, I mean … ehh forget I said anything.[/quote]

Not so. First, the client does not need to send its FOV data with every packet. That would be inefficient, as you put it. It is also completely unnecessary as the client does send deltas to the server. Rest assured, the server knows the precise value of all of your FOV markers. Think about it. The only way you can change your FOV directly is to move the arrow keys. Take a close look at their code and you will see that they are very careful to make absolutely certain they send themselves your FOV fields. The next logical question is ‘why do they do this?’. The answer to that question is: validation.

“All your clicks are belong to us”

Let me clarify one point that I don’t think that I have clarified before. As with anything anyone says about what the server could or couldn’t be doing, this is conjecture. The framework is there for them to literally validate every click. Does this mean they do it at runtime? I have no idea. I can think of a few ways to implement it in such a way that it wouldn’t cause more than a menial amount of overhead on the server. (Yes even with 2000 users…) Does this mean they have done it? Again, no idea. Could they though? Absolutely. Furthermore, I have a feeling there are very few developers that are allowed below a certain abstraction layer in the rs engine code. Most of the developers that work there, I wager a guess, only have access to the ‘scripting’ layer and work exclusively with impls provided to them by the core engine developer(s). The point of that statement was to illustrate that there are many dragons but only a few knights. Meaning… I think they probably rely quite heavily on ‘report abuse’ to start them on the trail of bots.

Read full topic

item.title: OpenGL textures and objects
item.dc:creator: @cooper cooper
item.description:
@cooper wrote:

[quote=“semaphore, post:37, topic:77833”]/unimpressed

Not that impressing me matters in any way.

First, let’s talk about your signature as it’s been mocked quite a bit. For clarity’s sake, anyone can be a ‘developer’ on second life, it’s an open ended game that allows users to ‘develop’ widgets. So I suppose in the loosest sense of the term you can call yourself an ‘official secondlife developer’. The one tidbit that I find somewhat amusing is that you added the tag ‘CodeManagement’. I don’t know a single developer, in all the years I’ve written code, that would willingly put the tag ‘CodeManagement’ in their title. Code Management is for the poor souls that can’t code. They handle builds. They manage CVS and CMS. They are most definitely not developers. They are scripters at best with maybe a modicum of understanding of high-level code. So that tag in your signature doesn’t really surprise me.[/quote]
Yes, but in full it says: “Offical Linden - SecondLife - Developer - CodeManagement”
The Developer part is agreeable with what you say, but the Official Linden part is the part that is most likely a lie. And if he has to lie about that, I just really don’t see him as a good developer. Maybe a furry griefer going to virtual sex spots, but thats about it.

Read full topic

item.title: OpenGL textures and objects
item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_
item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

semaphore:

If you change them and go about clicking on your new models, for example, making a tree a large cuboid, all it takes is one click that registers as a model hit on your machine but when it gets to the server, the server does a very simple check to validate the click location against 1. object location, 2. your location, 3. camera angle, 4, camera pitch, 5. real model data.

Even if the client camera and the server “camera” were always synchronized/the client sent its camera angle in every relevant packet, even by Jagexs standards that would have to be too inefficient.
Well, I mean … ehh forget I said anything.

Read full topic

item.title: OpenGL textures and objects
item.dc:creator: @semaphore semaphore
item.description:
@semaphore wrote:

/unimpressed

Not that impressing me matters in any way.

First, let’s talk about your signature as it’s been mocked quite a bit. For clarity’s sake, anyone can be a ‘developer’ on second life, it’s an open ended game that allows users to ‘develop’ widgets. So I suppose in the loosest sense of the term you can call yourself an ‘official secondlife developer’. The one tidbit that I find somewhat amusing is that you added the tag ‘CodeManagement’. I don’t know a single developer, in all the years I’ve written code, that would willingly put the tag ‘CodeManagement’ in their title. Code Management is for the poor souls that can’t code. They handle builds. They manage CVS and CMS. They are most definitely not developers. They are scripters at best with maybe a modicum of understanding of high-level code. So that tag in your signature doesn’t really surprise me.

And now for the point.

What are you hoping to accomplish? I don’t expect the community should expect much from you because all you have managed to do is figure out the format for the models in the game. Even that is debatable since bentski released his code quite a while ago and anyone really can just peruse his code and surmise the format. Also, editing the model files will be absolutely pointless for you because, if all you, seemingly, have done is figured out how to put the models onto a screen and maybe even edit them, there is no way in hell you will get them into the game. Is it possible you have figured out how to bypass the crc check on cache files? Sure, but do I think you did? Highly unlikely. What’s more, even if you do manage to modify the models in the game, what in the hell makes you think that is not detectable? If you change them and go about clicking on your new models, for example, making a tree a large cuboid, all it takes is one click that registers as a model hit on your machine but when it gets to the server, the server does a very simple check to validate the click location against 1. object location, 2. your location, 3. camera angle, 4, camera pitch, 5. real model data. Granted, the check very likely does not happen real time. But, it does happen, and when it does you are caught.

Nice to meet you.

edit: ok bang train, private servers would be one use for it. good point.

Read full topic

item.title: OpenGL textures and objects
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

LindenProg:

Here is what you guys have been waiting for the 3d object exported into .obj file

I’m just curious about a few things.

For one thing, this model is pretty inefficient. I mean this is no problem for a model or two, but does jagex do this to all of their models?

For instance, here there are 8 triangles when there could be 2. That’s not a big difference, but when you do stuff like this often all those triangles add up.

And I was wondering why the model is on such a strange slant? It doesn’t make very much sense.

Of course, maybe these flaws are created through the conversion, but I wouldn’t have a clue.

Read full topic

Also, they want 5 years professional experience of some things… so yeah unless he was a VERY active [and nerdy :P] teenager its very improbable.
